step.name: ifStep

pre.b: Provides the ability for conditional testing. The step takes either one of the two attributes test and unless, or a single nested element condition. Exactly one of these must have a value.

step.name: setRadioButton
step.description: Provides the ability to check radio buttons in <key>HTML</key> forms.

pre.b: The radio button to set will be determined by finding the appropriate form followed by finding the appropriate field on that form.
Simple Form Selection: in many cases, your page will only have one form - that form will be used - you don't need to worry about trying to select the form.
Tricky Form Selection: if no last response is available, the step fails. Otherwise, the form to use is chosen as follows:

li.dd: If an explicit formName is given and the named form has a suitable field, that is used.
If the current form has been previously set and it has a suitable field, that is used.
All forms from the last response are searched until one is found with a suitable field.

pre.b: If no such form is found, the step fails. If a form is found, it is then considered as the current form for future steps.

Simple Field Selection: in many cases, only one field will match the name and value of the field you are interested in. In these cases, you don't need to worry about the remaining details for selecting fields.
Tricky Field Selection: if a suitable form is found, the field is chosen as follows:

li.dd: First find all potential fields on the selected form having the correct name.
Remove any fields which don't match the specified value (if specified).
Fail if no fields remain or if the specified fieldIndex doesn't correspond to any of the found fields (i.e. is out of range).
If fieldIndex is specified, return the corresponding field.
Return the first field found.

pre.b: NOTE: if you need, you can verify the value of a radio button using the step with attributeName='checked'. It should return checked if the radio button is checked and false otherwise.

parameter.description: The description of this test step.

parameter.name: value
parameter.description: The value to use to find the desired radio-button. Must be specified if name is specified.

nestedParameter.name: addText

parameter.default: the last form selected using 'selectForm', otherwise searches all forms
parameter.description: The name of the form containing the field of interest. Ignored if htmlId is used.

parameter.description: The id of the input field of interest. One of forLabel, htmlId, name, or xpath is required.

parameter.name: fieldIndex
parameter.default: the first field found that matches criteria
parameter.description: The index of the field of interest (starting at 0) if more than one field matches criteria. Ignored if htmlId or xpath is used.

parameter.name: save
parameter.description: A shorthand: save='prefixName' is the same as savePrefix='prefixName' saveResponse='true'.

parameter.name: savePrefix
parameter.description: A name prefix can be specified for making a permanent copy of received responses. A unique number and the file extension (depending on the MIME-Type) will be appended. The resultpath attribute of the element is used for determining the location of the saved result.

parameter.name: saveResponse
parameter.description: Whether to make a permanent copy of received responses. Overrides the default value set in the <config> element.

post.b: NOTE: there is no facility to unset a radio button. This is not normally needed. When you set a radio button, all radio buttons with the same name in the same form are 'unset' automatically. So either no radio buttons have been selected (if your application didn't provide a default) or exactly one is set. The only time you need to worry about the no radio button case is if your application doesn't provide a default. If this is the case, simply load the page in question, don't explicitly set any radio buttons, and perform your tests.

Advanced Note: strictly speaking it is possible that via greasemonkey scripts, proxies or other means, someone could maliciously (or via accident) remove a checked setting on a radio button even if your application always provided a default. So you should make your application do something graceful in those cases and we may need to eventually provide an <forceUnsetRadioButton> step to allow testing of this very rare scenario.

step.name: expectDialog
step.description: Provides the ability to set expectations in relation to user responses to <key>javascript</key> Dialog boxes (Alert, Confirm and Prompt dialogs).

pre.b: This step is used prior to clicking on a link or button which invokes some javascript that uses dialogs (Alert, Confirm or Prompt dialogs). If you don't use this step, CWT simply clicks 'OK' on every dialog silently. This is OK if you don't care about the Dialogs, but if you do care, you have no way of telling if anything was actually clicked or what messages were displayed in the dialogs.

You may be wondering why you need to set up expectations prior to clicking on a link or button. This is mostly due to implementation issues with the way CWT works and the way it calls htmlunit . It turns out to be easier at the moment to create a list of dialog expectations. As interactions with your application cause javascript to invoke dialogs, we simply look at the next dialog expectation on the list, check that it meets expectations (or optionally save away the dialog message text) and then remove it from the list. For tricky javascript there may be multiple interactions from the user. We simply list all the expected dialog interactions in the order we expect them to occur by repeating this step as many times as required. (Alternatively, consider using the newer step which allows more concise expression of dialog sequences.)

Often you will use the
step in conjunction with this step to ensure that your expectations for dialogs were met. The
step is used after clicking on your link or button - it checks that the list of expected dialogs is now empty, i.e. by the time you have finished interacting with your application all the dialogs you were expecting to need clicking were actually clicked.

pre.b: This step is used prior to clicking on a link or button which invokes some javascript that uses dialogs (Alert, Confirm or Prompt dialogs). If you don't use this step, CWT simply clicks 'OK' on every dialog silently. This is OK if you don't care about the Dialogs, but if you do care, you have no way of telling if anything was actually clicked or what messages were displayed in the dialogs.

You may be wondering why you need to set up expectations prior to clicking on a link or button. This is mostly due to implementation issues with the way CWT works and the way it calls htmlunit. It turns out to be easier at the moment to create a list of dialog expectations. As interactions with your application cause javascript to invoke dialogs, we simply look at the next dialog expectation on the list, check that it meets expectations (or optionally save away the dialog message text) and then remove it from the list. For tricky javascript there may be multiple interactions from the user. We simply list all the expected dialog interactions in the order we expect them to occur.

Often you will use the
step in conjunction with this step to ensure that your expectations for dialogs were met. The
step is used after clicking on your link or button - it checks that the list of expected dialogs is now empty, i.e. by the time you have finished interacting with your application all the dialogs you were expecting to need clicking were actually clicked.

step.name: scriptStep
step.description: Provides the ability to use scripting code in your tests.

pre.b: ANT has a normal style requiring declarative specification of your build tasks. If you find this too limiting in certain scenarios, Ant provides a script task which lets you dive into (non-declarative) scripting code. The same need occurs within your CWT steps; perhaps you need to do something not supported by the standard steps, or perhaps you wish to perform some tests in a way better-suited to programmatic rather than declarative means.

This step helps in these scenarios by providing a wrapper around the ANT script task. Before providing the supplied script to the ANT script task, scriptStep expands any WebTest dynamic properties and defines some useful variables. Results from running the script can be made available for subsequent steps to use.

The language must be one of those supported by the BSF which means one of javascript, Python (using either Jython or JPython), Tcl (using Jacl), NetRexx, XSLT Stylesheets, Java (using BeanShell), JRuby, groovy, ObjectScript, and JudoScript. See also the BSF documentation for other languages which BSF has supported in the past - you might be able to get other languages working with a bit of work.

WebTest has all the necessary files to support groovy and javascript natively (and also XSLT but it isn't usually used directly). For other languages you will need to download the necessary support files - usually just one jar - and update your classpath appropriately.
Note: although scriptStep does support javascript, at the moment, it doesn't provide the mechanism to call JavaScript functions in your HTML pages under test.

parameter.description: The description of this test step.

parameter.name: contentType
parameter.description: The contentType. The contentType to use for a Simple message with uuencoded attachments. For MIME MultiPart messages, the contentType if supplied is checked against the contentType found.

parameter.name: partIndex
parameter.description: The part index.

parameter.name: save
parameter.description: A shorthand: save='prefixName' is the same as savePrefix='prefixName' saveResponse='true'.

parameter.name: savePrefix
parameter.description: A name prefix can be specified for making a permanent copy of received responses. A unique number and the file extension (depending on the MIME-Type) will be appended. The resultpath attribute of the element is used for determining the location of the saved result.

parameter.name: saveResponse
parameter.description: Whether to make a permanent copy of received responses. Overrides the default value set in the <config> element.

parameter.name: messageId
parameter.description: The message id.

step.name: excelVerifyCellValue
step.description: This step verifies the value of a specified cell in an Excel spreadsheet. Note that this step tests the actual stored value of the cell, not what is displayed in the spreadsheet. In particular, formulas will not be evaluated.

parameter.name: description
parameter.description: The description of this test step.

parameter.name: text
parameter.description: The text value to verify against.

parameter.name: cell
parameter.description: The spreadsheet cell to select. eg. A5. Either cell or row and col must be specified.

parameter.name: row
parameter.description: The number of the row to select, starting at 1. Either cell or row and col must be specified.

parameter.name: col
parameter.description: The name or number (starting at 1) of the column to select. eg 1 or A. Either cell or row and col must be specified.

parameter.name: sheetName
parameter.description: The name of the sheet to select. If no sheet is selected, the value of the last excelSelectSheet call is used, or defaults to the first sheet.

parameter.name: sheetIndex
parameter.description: The index of the sheet to select, starting at zero. If no sheet is selected, the value of the last excelSelectSheet call is used, or defaults to the first sheet.

step.name: pdfVerifyReadOnlyField
step.description: This step verifies the read-only status of a field in the <key>pdf</key> document.

parameter.name: description
parameter.description: The description of this test step.

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of the field

parameter.name: readOnly
parameter.description: Specifies whether the field is expected to be read-only or not.

parameter.name: page
parameter.description: The numeric value of the page to restrict the verification to.

step.name: emailStoreMessageCount
step.description: Stores the number of messages (optionally matching provided criteria) into a property.

parameter.name: description
parameter.description: The description of this test step.

parameter.name: subject
parameter.description: The email Subject header field.

parameter.name: from
parameter.description: The email From header field.

parameter.name: to
parameter.description: The email To header field.

parameter.name: cc
parameter.description: The email Cc header field.

parameter.name: replyTo
parameter.description: The email ReplyTo header field.

parameter.name: property
parameter.description: The target property name.

parameter.name: propertyType
parameter.default: the "defaultPropertyType" as specified in the "config" element is used.
parameter.description: The target property type. Either "ant" or "dynamic".

post.b: See the documentation for an example of using this step.

Note that subject and the email address attributes (to, from, cc and replyTo) are used for matching purposes to select a subset of the available messages. Each can be either plain text or a regex. Simply start and end them with the "/" character to make them a regex. If all of these are left blank, all messages will be selected for counting. In addition, to, cc and replyTo may contain a comma (",") separated list of email addresses. Each address must appear in an email message for it to match - order is not important.

step.name: mouseOver
step.description: Triggers a mouseOver event on the HTML element identified by its id or xpath. If this triggers the load of a new page, then this page becomes the current one.

parameter.name: description
parameter.description: The description of this test step.

parameter.name: htmlId
parameter.description: The id of the HTML element to trigger the event on. One of htmlId or xPath must be set.

parameter.name: xpath
parameter.description: The XPath identifying the HTL element to trigger the event on. One of htmlId or xPath must be set.

step.name: pdfVerifyEncryptionProperty
step.description: This step verifies a property of the encrypt dictionary from an encrypted pdf document. The step must either verify the existence of the encrypt dictionary property key or it must verify its value.

parameter.name: description
parameter.description: The description of this test step.

parameter.name: key
parameter.description: The text of the encrypt dictionary property key.

parameter.name: exists
parameter.description: Specifies whether the property/field of interest is expected to exist or not. Must not be set if 'value' attribute is set.

parameter.name: regex
parameter.description: Specifies whether the value represents a <key>regex</key>.

parameter.name: value
parameter.description: The text/<key>regex</key> required to match the property/field of interest. Must not be set if 'exists' attribute is set.
